fields.name: createCampaign
fields.description:
Create a campaign from a campaign spec and locally computed changeset specs. The newly created
campaign is returned.
If a campaign in the same namespace with the same name already exists, an error with the error code
ErrMatchingCampaignExists is returned.

args.name: campaignSpec
args.description: The campaign spec that describes the desired state of the campaign.

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use createBatchChange instead.

fields.name: applyCampaign
fields.description:
Create or update a campaign from a campaign spec and locally computed changeset specs. If no
campaign exists in the namespace with the name given in the campaign spec, a campaign will be
created. Otherwise, the existing campaign will be updated. The campaign is returned.
Closed campaigns cannot be applied to. In that case, an error with the error code ErrApplyClosedCampaign
will be returned.

args.name: campaignSpec
args.description: The campaign spec that describes the new desired state of the campaign.

args.name: ensureCampaign
args.description:
If set, return an error if the campaign identified using the namespace and campaignSpec
parameters does not match the campaign with this ID. This lets callers use a stable ID
that refers to a specific campaign during an edit session (and is not susceptible to
conflicts if the underlying campaign is moved to a different namespace, renamed, or
deleted). The returned error has the error code ErrEnsureCampaignFailed.

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use applyBatchChange instead.

fields.name: moveCampaign
fields.description: Move a campaign to a different namespace, or rename it in the current namespace.
fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use moveBatchChange instead.

fields.name: closeCampaign
fields.description: Close a campaign.

args.name: closeChangesets
args.description:
Whether to close the changesets associated with this campaign on their respective code
hosts. "Close" means the appropriate final state on the code host (e.g., "closed" on
GitHub and "declined" on Bitbucket Server).

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use closeBatchChange instead.

fields.name: deleteCampaign
fields.description:
Delete a campaign. A deleted campaign is completely removed and can't be un-deleted. The
campaign's changesets are kept as-is; to close them, use the closeCampaign mutation first.
fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use deleteBatchChange instead.

fields.name: createCampaignSpec
fields.description:
Create a campaign spec that will be used to create a campaign (with the createCampaign
mutation), or to update a campaign (with the applyCampaign mutation).

The returned CampaignSpec is immutable and expires after a certain period of time (if not used
in a call to applyCampaign), which can be queried on CampaignSpec.expiresAt.

If campaigns are unlicensed and the number of changesetSpecIDs is higher than what's allowed in
the free tier, an error with the error code ErrCampaignsUnlicensed is returned.

args.name: namespace
args.description:
The namespace (either a user or organization). A campaign spec can only be applied to (or
used to create) campaigns in this namespace.

args.name: campaignSpec
args.description:
The campaign spec as YAML (or the equivalent JSON). See
https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/schema/campaign_spec.schema.json
for the JSON Schema that describes the structure of this input.

args.name: changesetSpecs
args.description: Changeset specs that were locally computed and then uploaded using createChangesetSpec.

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use createBatchSpec instead.

fields.name: createCampaignsCredential
fields.description:
Create a new credential for the given user for the given code host.
If another token for that code host already exists, an error with the error code
ErrDuplicateCredential is returned.

args.name: user
args.description: The user for which to create the credential.

args.name: externalServiceKind
args.description: The kind of external service being configured.

args.name: externalServiceURL
args.description: The URL of the external service being configured.

args.name: credential
args.description: The credential to be stored. This can never be retrieved through the API and will be stored encrypted.

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use createBatchChangesCredential instead.

fields.name: deleteCampaignsCredential
fields.description: Hard-deletes a given campaigns credential.
fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use deleteBatchChangesCredential instead.

fields.name: createChangesetSpec
fields.description:
Upload a changeset spec that will be used in a future update to a batch change. The changeset spec
is stored and can be referenced by its ID in the applyBatchChange mutation. Just uploading the
changeset spec does not result in changes to the batch change or any of its changesets; you need
to call applyBatchChange to use it.

You can use this mutation to upload large changeset specs (e.g., containing large diffs) in
individual HTTP requests. Then, in the eventual applyBatchChange call, you just refer to the
changeset specs by their IDs. This lets you avoid problems when updating large batch changes where
a large HTTP request body (e.g., with many large diffs in the changeset specs) would be
rejected by the web server/proxy or would be very slow.

The returned ChangesetSpec is immutable and expires after a certain period of time (if not
used in a call to applyBatchChange), which can be queried on ChangesetSpec.expiresAt.

args.name: changesetSpec
args.description:
The raw changeset spec (as JSON). See
https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/schema/changeset_spec.schema.json
for the JSON Schema that describes the structure of this input.

fields.name: syncChangeset
fields.description: Enqueue the given changeset for high-priority syncing.

fields.name: reenqueueChangeset
fields.description: Re-enqueue the changeset for processing by the reconciler. The changeset must be in FAILED state.

fields.name: createBatchChange
fields.description:
Create a batch change from a batch spec and locally computed changeset specs. The newly created
batch change is returned.
If a batch change in the same namespace with the same name already exists,
an error with the error code ErrMatchingBatchChangeExists is returned.

args.name: batchSpec
args.description: The batch spec that describes the desired state of the batch change.

args.name: publicationStates
args.description:
If set, these changeset specs will have their UI publication states set
to the given values.

An error will be returned if the same changeset spec ID is included
more than once in the array, or if a changeset spec ID is included with
a publication state set in its spec.

fields.name: createBatchSpec
fields.description:
Create a batch spec that will be used to create a batch change (with the createBatchChange
mutation), or to update an existing batch change (with the applyBatchChange mutation).

The returned BatchSpec is immutable and expires after a certain period of time (if not used
in a call to applyBatchChange), which can be queried on BatchSpec.expiresAt.

If batch changes are unlicensed and the number of changesetSpecIDs is higher than what's allowed in
the free tier, an error with the error code ErrCampaignsUnlicensed is returned.

args.name: namespace
args.description:
The namespace (either a user or organization). A batch spec can only be applied to (or
used to create) batch changes in this namespace.

args.name: batchSpec
args.description:
The batch spec as YAML (or the equivalent JSON). See
https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph/-/blob/schema/campaign_spec.schema.json
for the JSON Schema that describes the structure of this input.

args.name: changesetSpecs
args.description: Changeset specs that were locally computed and then uploaded using createChangesetSpec.

fields.name: applyBatchChange
fields.description:
Create or update a batch change from a batch spec and locally computed changeset specs. If no
batch change exists in the namespace with the name given in the batch spec, a batch change will be
created. Otherwise, the existing batch change will be updated. The batch change is returned.
Closed batch changes cannot be applied to. In that case, an error with the error code ErrApplyClosedbatch change
will be returned.

args.name: batchSpec
args.description: The batch spec that describes the new desired state of the batch change.

args.name: ensureBatchChange
args.description:
If set, return an error if the batch change identified using the namespace and batch changeSpec
parameters does not match the batch change with this ID. This lets callers use a stable ID
that refers to a specific batch change during an edit session (and is not susceptible to
conflicts if the underlying batch change is moved to a different namespace, renamed, or
deleted). The returned error has the error code ErrEnsureBatchChangeFailed.

args.name: publicationStates
args.description:
If set, these changeset specs will have their UI publication states set
to the given values. This will overwrite any existing UI publication
states on the changesets.

An error will be returned if the same changeset spec ID is included
more than once in the array, or if a changeset spec ID is included with
a publication state set in its spec.

fields.name: closeBatchChange
fields.description: Close a batch change.

args.name: closeChangesets
args.description:
Whether to close the changesets associated with this batch change on their respective code
hosts. "Close" means the appropriate final state on the code host (e.g., "closed" on
GitHub and "declined" on Bitbucket Server).

fields.name: moveBatchChange
fields.description: Move a batch change to a different namespace, or rename it in the current namespace.

fields.name: deleteBatchChange
fields.description:
Delete a batch change. A deleted batch change is completely removed and can't be un-deleted. The
batch change's changesets are kept as-is; to close them, use the closeBatchChange mutation first.

fields.name: createBatchChangesCredential
fields.description:
Create a new credential for the given user for the given code host.
If another token for that code host already exists, an error with the error code
ErrDuplicateCredential is returned.

args.name: user
args.description: The user for which to create the credential. If null is provided, a site-wide credential is created.

args.name: externalServiceKind
args.description: The kind of external service being configured.

args.name: externalServiceURL
args.description: The URL of the external service being configured.

args.name: credential
args.description: The credential to be stored. This can never be retrieved through the API and will be stored encrypted.

fields.name: deleteBatchChangesCredential
fields.description: Hard-deletes a given credential.

fields.name: detachChangesets
fields.description:
Detach archived changesets from a batch change.

Experimental: This API is likely to change in the future.

fields.name: createChangesetComments
fields.description:
Comment on multiple changesets from a batch change.

Experimental: This API is likely to change in the future.

fields.name: reenqueueChangesets
fields.description:
Reenqueue multiple changesets for processing.

Experimental: This API is likely to change in the future.

fields.name: mergeChangesets
fields.description:
Merge multiple changesets. If squash is true, the commits will be squashed
into a single commit on code hosts that support squash-and-merge.

Experimental: This API is likely to change in the future.

fields.name: closeChangesets
fields.description:
Close multiple changesets.

Experimental: This API is likely to change in the future.

fields.name: publishChangesets
fields.description:
Set the UI publication state for multiple changesets. If draft is true, the
changesets are published as drafts, provided the code host supports it.

Experimental: This API is likely to change in the future.

fields.name: createBatchSpecExecution
fields.description:
Creates a new batch spec execution from a given batch spec yaml file input.
The execution will be queued for processing by an executor. If some are available
for work, they will pick this up eventually.


If namespace is not specified, the current user's personal namespace is used.

fields.name: cancelBatchSpecExecution
fields.description: Attempts to cancel the given batch spec execution. It must not have completed yet.

fields.name: createCodeIntelligenceConfigurationPolicy
fields.description: Creates a new configuration policy with the given attributes.

args.name: repository
args.description:
If supplied, the repository to which this configuration policy applies. If not supplied,
this configuration policy is applied to all repositories.

fields.name: updateCodeIntelligenceConfigurationPolicy
fields.description: Updates the attributes configuration policy with the given identifier.

fields.name: deleteCodeIntelligenceConfigurationPolicy
fields.description: Deletes the configuration policy with the given identifier.

fields.name: updateRepositoryIndexConfiguration
fields.description: Updates the indexing configuration associated with a repository.

fields.name: queueAutoIndexJobsForRepo
fields.description:
Queues the index jobs for a repository for execution. An optional resolvable revhash
(commit, branch name, or tag name) can be specified; by default the tip of the default
branch will be used.

If a configuration is supplied, that configuration is used to determine what jobs to
schedule. If no configuration is supplied, it will go through the regular index scheduling
rules: first read any in-repo configuration (e.g., sourcegraph.yaml), then look for any
existing in-database configuration, finally falling back to the automatically inferred
connfiguration based on the repo contents at the target commit.

fields.name: deleteLSIFUpload

fields.name: deleteLSIFIndex

Set the permissions of a repository (i.e., which users may view it on Sourcegraph). This
operation overwrites the previous permissions for the repository.

args.name: repository

args.name: userPermissions
args.description:
A list of user identifiers and their repository permissions, which defines the set of
users who may view the repository. All users not included in the list will not be
permitted to view the repository on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: scheduleRepositoryPermissionsSync
fields.description:
Schedule a permissions sync for given repository. This queries the repository's code host for
all users' permissions associated with the repository, so that the current permissions apply
to all users' operations on that repository on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: scheduleUserPermissionsSync
fields.description:
Schedule a permissions sync for given user. This queries all code hosts for the user's current
repository permissions and syncs them to Sourcegraph, so that the current permissions apply to
the user's operations on Sourcegraph.

args.name: user
args.description: User to schedule a sync for.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options when performing a sync.

types.name: OutOfBandMigration
types.description:
An out-of-band migration is a process that runs in the background of the instance that moves
data from one format into another format. Out-of-band migrations

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique identifier of this migration.

fields.name: team
fields.description: The team that owns this migration (e.g., code-intelligence).

fields.name: component
fields.description: The component this migration affects (e.g., codeintel-db.lsif_data_documents).

fields.name: description
fields.description: A human-readable summary of the migration.

fields.name: introduced
fields.description:
The Sourcegraph version in which this migration was introduced. The format of this version
includes only major and minor parts separated by a dot. The patch version can always be assumed
to be zero as we'll never introduce or deprecate an out-of-band migration within a patch release.

It is necessary to completely this migration in reverse (if destructive) before downgrading
to or past this version. Otherwise, the previous instance version will not be aware of the
new data format.

fields.name: deprecated
fields.description:
The Sourcegraph version by which this migration is assumed to have completed. The format of
this version mirrors introduced and includes only major and minor parts separated by a dot.

It is necessary to have completed this migration before upgrading to or past this version.
Otherwsie, the next instance version will no longer be aware of the old data format.

fields.name: progress
fields.description: The progress of the migration (in the forward direction). In the range [0, 1].

fields.name: created
fields.description: The time the migration record was inserted.

fields.name: lastUpdated
fields.description: The last time the migration progress or error list was updated.

fields.name: nonDestructive
fields.description:
If false, the migration moves data destructively, and a previous version of Sourcegraph
will encounter errors when interfacing with the target data unless the migration is first
run in reverse prior to a downgrade.

fields.name: applyReverse
fields.description: If true, the migration will run in reverse.

fields.name: errors
fields.description:
A list of errors that have occurred while performing this migration (in either direction).
This list is bounded by a maximum size, and older errors will replaced by newer errors as
the list capacity is reached.

types.name: OutOfBandMigrationError
types.description: An error that occurred while performing an out-of-band migration.

fields.name: message
fields.description: The error message.

fields.name: created
fields.description: The time the error occurred.

A preview of an invoice that would be generated for a new or updated product subscription.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

fields.description:
The net price for this invoice, in USD cents. If this invoice represents an update to a
subscription, this is the difference between the existing price and the updated price.

fields.name: prorationDate
fields.description:
For updates to existing subscriptions, the effective date for which this preview invoice was
calculated, expressed as the number of seconds since the epoch. For new subscriptions, this is
null.

fields.name: isDowngradeRequiringManualIntervention
fields.description: Whether this invoice requires manual intervention.

fields.description:
The "before" state of the product subscription (i.e., the existing subscription), prior to the update that this preview
represents, or null if the preview is for a new subscription.

fields.name: afterInvoiceItem
fields.description:
The "after" state of the product subscription, with the update applied to the subscription.
For new subscriptions, this is just the invoice item for the subscription that will be
created.

fields.description:
The date and time when the max number of user accounts that have been active on this Sourcegraph site for
the current license was reached. If no license is in use, returns an empty string.

fields.name: maximumAllowedUserCount
fields.description:
The number of users allowed. If there is a license, this is equal to ProductLicenseInfo.userCount. Otherwise,
it is the user limit for instances without a license, or null if there is no limit.

fields.name: noLicenseWarningUserCount
fields.description:
The number of free users allowed on a site without a license before a warning is shown to all users, or null
if a valid license is in use.

fields.name: license
fields.description: The product license associated with this subscription, if any.

args.description:
Query the repository by a Git clone URL (format documented here: https://git-scm.com/docs/git-clone_git_urls_a_id_urls_a)
by checking for a code host configuration that matches the clone URL.

and "disablePublicRepoRedirects" is "false" in the site configuration, it returns a Redirect to
an external Sourcegraph URL that may have this repository instead. Otherwise, this query returns
null.

args.description:

by checking for a code host configuration that matches the clone URL.
Will not actually check the code host to see if the repository actually exists.

created by org1 + contexts created by org2 + all instance-level contexts.

args.name: query
args.description:
An (optional) search query that searches over the state, repository name,
commit, root, and indexer properties.

args.name: state
args.description: The state of returned uploads.

args.name: dependencyOf
args.description: When specified, shows only uploads that are a dependency of the specified upload.

args.name: dependentOf
args.description: When specified, shows only uploads that are a dependent of the specified upload.

args.name: isLatestForRepo
args.description: When specified, shows only uploads that are latest for the given repository.

args.name: first
args.description:
When specified, indicates that this request should be paginated and
the first N results (relative to the cursor) should be returned. i.e.
how many results to return per page. It must be in the range of 0-5000.

args.name: after
args.description:
When specified, indicates that this request should be paginated and
to fetch results starting at this cursor.

A future request can be made for more results by passing in the
'LSIFUploadConnection.pageInfo.endCursor' that is returned.

fields.name: authorizedUserRepositories
fields.description:
The repositories a user is authorized to access with the given permission.
This isn’t defined in the User type because we store permissions for users
that don’t yet exist (i.e. late binding). Only one of "username" or "email"
is required to identify a user.

args.name: username

args.name: email

args.name: perm
args.description: Permission that the user has on the repositories.

args.name: first
args.description: Number of repositories to return after the given cursor.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

fields.description:
Returns a list of usernames or emails that have associated pending permissions.
The returned list can be used to query authorizedUserRepositories for pending permissions.

types.name: RegistryExtension
types.description: An extension's listing in the extension registry.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
The unique, opaque, permanent ID of the extension. Do not display this ID to the user; display
RegistryExtension.extensionID instead (it is friendlier and still unique, but it can be renamed).

fields.name: uuid
fields.description:
The UUID of the extension. This identifies the extension externally (along with the origin). The UUID maps
1-to-1 to RegistryExtension.id.

fields.name: publisher
fields.description: The publisher of the extension. If this extension is from a remote registry, the publisher may be null.

fields.name: extensionID
fields.description:
The qualified, unique name that refers to this extension, consisting of the registry name (if non-default),
publisher's name, and the extension's name, all joined by "/" (for example, "acme-corp/my-extension-name").

fields.name: extensionIDWithoutRegistry
fields.description: The extension ID without the registry name.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the extension (not including the publisher's name).

fields.name: manifest
fields.description: The extension manifest, or null if none is set.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The date when this extension was created on the registry.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description:
The date when this extension was last updated on the registry (including updates to its metadata only, not
publishing new releases).

fields.name: publishedAt
fields.description: The date when a release of this extension was most recently published, or null if there are no releases.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL to the extension on this Sourcegraph site.

fields.name: remoteURL
fields.description:
The URL to the extension on the extension registry where it lives (if this is a remote
extension). If this extension is local, then this field's value is null.

fields.name: registryName
fields.description: The name of this extension's registry.

fields.name: isLocal
fields.description: Whether the registry extension is published on this Sourcegraph site.

fields.name: isWorkInProgress
fields.description: Whether the extension is marked as a work-in-progress extension by the extension author.

fields.name: viewerCanAdminister
fields.description: Whether the viewer has admin privileges on this registry extension.

types.name: RegistryExtensionConnection
types.description: A list of registry extensions.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of registry extensions.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description:
The total count of registry extensions in the connection. This total count may be larger than the number of
nodes in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL to this list, or null if none exists.

fields.name: error
fields.description:
Errors that occurred while communicating with remote registries to obtain the list of extensions.
In order to be able to return local extensions even when the remote registry is unreachable, errors are
recorded here instead of in the top-level GraphQL errors list.

types.name: RegistryPublisher

types.name: RegistryPublisherConnection

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of publishers.

The total count of publishers in the connection. This total count may be larger than the number of
nodes in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: Repository
types.description: A repository is a Git source control repository that is mirrored from some origin code host.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The repository's unique ID.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
The repository's name, as a path with one or more components. It conventionally consists of
the repository's hostname and path (joined by "/"), minus any suffixes (such as ".git").
Examples:
- github.com/foo/bar
- my-code-host.example.com/myrepo
- myrepo

fields.name: uri
fields.description: DEPRECATED: Use name.
fields.deprecationReason: Use name.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The repository's description.

fields.name: language
fields.description: The primary programming language in the repository.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description:
DEPRECATED: This field is unused in known clients.
The date when this repository was created on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description:
DEPRECATED: This field is unused in known clients.
The date when this repository's metadata was last updated on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: commit
fields.description: Returns information about the given commit in the repository, or null if no commit exists with the given rev.

args.name: rev
args.description: The Git revision specifier (revspec) for the commit.

args.name: inputRevspec
args.description:
Optional input revspec used to construct non-canonical URLs and other "friendly" field values. Used by
clients that must ensure consistency of revision resolution within a session/request (so they use full
SHAs) but also preserve the user input rev (for user friendliness).

fields.name: mirrorInfo
fields.description:
Information and status related to mirroring, if this repository is a mirror of another repository (e.g., on
some code host). In this case, the remote source repository is external to Sourcegraph and the mirror is
maintained by the Sourcegraph site (not the other way around).

fields.name: externalRepository
fields.description:
Information about this repository from the external service that it originates from (such as GitHub, GitLab,
Phabricator, etc.).

fields.name: isFork
fields.description: Whether the repository is a fork.

fields.name: isArchived
fields.description: Whether the repository has been archived.

fields.name: isPrivate
fields.description: Whether the repository is private.

fields.name: externalServices
fields.description: Lists all external services which yield this repository.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n external services from the list.

fields.name: cloneInProgress
fields.description: Whether the repository is currently being cloned.
fields.deprecationReason: use Repository.mirrorInfo.cloneInProgress instead

fields.name: textSearchIndex
fields.description:
Information about the text search index for this repository, or null if text search indexing
is not enabled or supported for this repository.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL to this repository.

fields.name: externalURLs
fields.description: The URLs to this repository on external services associated with it.

fields.name: defaultBranch
fields.description:
The repository's default Git branch (HEAD symbolic ref). If the repository is currently being cloned or is
empty, this field will be null.

fields.name: gitRefs
fields.description: The repository's Git refs.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n Git refs from the list.

args.name: query
args.description: Return Git refs whose names match the query.

args.name: type
args.description:
Return only Git refs of the given type.
Known issue: It is only supported to retrieve Git branch and tag refs, not
other Git refs.

args.name: orderBy
args.description: Ordering for Git refs in the list.

args.name: interactive
args.description:
Ordering is an expensive operation that doesn't scale for lots of
references. If this is true we fallback on not ordering. This should
never be false in interactive API requests.

fields.name: branches
fields.description: The repository's Git branches.

args.description:
Ordering is an expensive operation that doesn't scale for lots of

args.name: fetchMissing

A list of authorized users to access this repository with the given permission.
This API currently only returns permissions from the Sourcegraph provider, i.e.

The permissions information of the repository for the authenticated user.
It is null when there is no permissions data stored for the repository.

types.name: RepositoryComparison
types.description: The differences between two concrete Git commits in a repository.

fields.name: baseRepository
fields.description: The repository that is the base (left-hand side) of this comparison.

fields.name: headRepository
fields.description:
The repository that is the head (right-hand side) of this comparison. Cross-repository
comparisons are not yet supported, so this is always equal to
RepositoryComparison.baseRepository.

fields.name: range
fields.description: The range that this comparison represents.

fields.name: commits
fields.description: The commits in the comparison range, excluding the base and including the head.

args.name: first
args.description: Return the first n commits from the list.

fields.name: fileDiffs
fields.description: The file diffs for each changed file.

args.name: first
args.description: Return the first n file diffs from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Return file diffs after the given cursor.

fields.description:
The total count of repositories in the connection. This total count may be larger
than the number of nodes in this object when the result is paginated.
This requires admin permissions and will return null for all non-admin users.
In some cases, the total count can't be computed quickly; if so, it is null. Pass
precise: true to always compute total counts even if it takes a while.

fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: RepositoryTextSearchIndexedRef
types.description: A Git ref (usually a branch) in a repository that is configured to be indexed for text search.

fields.name: ref
fields.description:
The Git ref (usually a branch) that is configured to be indexed for text search. To find the specific commit
SHA that was indexed, use RepositoryTextSearchIndexedRef.indexedCommit; this field's ref target resolves to
the current target, not the target at the time of indexing.

fields.name: indexed
fields.description: Whether a text search index exists for this ref.

fields.name: current
fields.description: Whether the text search index is of the current commit for the Git ref. If false, the index is stale.

fields.name: indexedCommit
fields.description:
The indexed Git commit (which may differ from the ref's current target if the index is out of date). If
indexed is false, this field's value is null.

types.name: SearchContext
types.description: A search context. Specifies a set of repositories to be searched.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The unique id of the search context.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the search context.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: The owner (user or org) of the search context. If nil, search context is considered instance-level.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the search context.

fields.name: spec
fields.description:
Fully-qualified search context spec for use when querying.
Examples: global, @username, @username/ctx, and @org/ctx.

fields.name: autoDefined
fields.description:
Whether the search context is autodefined by Sourcegraph. Current examples include:
global search context ("global"), default user search context ("@user"), and
default organization search context ("@org").

fields.name: repositories
fields.description: Repositories and their revisions that will be searched when querying.

fields.name: public
fields.description:
Public property controls the visibility of the search context. Public search context is available to
any user on the instance. If a public search context contains private repositories, those are filtered out
for unauthorized users. Private search contexts are only available to their owners. Private user search context
is available only to the user, private org search context is available only to the members of the org, and private
instance-level search contexts are available only to site-admins.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: Date and time the search context was last updated.

fields.name: viewerCanManage
fields.description: If current viewer can manage (edit, delete) the search context.

types.name: SearchContextConnection
types.description: A list of search contexts

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of search contexts.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description: The total number of search contexts in the connection.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: SearchContextEditInput
types.description: Input for editing an existing search context.

inputFields.name: name
inputFields.description:
Search context name. Not the same as the search context spec. Search context namespace and search context name
are used to construct the fully-qualified search context spec.
Example mappings from search context spec to search context name: global -> global, @user -> user, @org -> org,
@user/ctx1 -> ctx1, @org/ctxs/ctx -> ctxs/ctx.

inputFields.name: description
inputFields.description: Search context description.

inputFields.name: public
inputFields.description:
Public property controls the visibility of the search context. Public search context is available to
any user on the instance. If a public search context contains private repositories, those are filtered out
for unauthorized users. Private search contexts are only available to their owners. Private user search context
is available only to the user, private org search context is available only to the members of the org, and private
instance-level search contexts are available only to site-admins.

@user/ctx1 -> ctx1, @org/ctxs/ctx -> ctxs/ctx.

inputFields.description:
Public property controls the visibility of the search context. Public search context is available to
any user on the instance. If a public search context contains private repositories, those are filtered out
for unauthorized users. Private search contexts are only available to their owners. Private user search context
is available only to the user, private org search context is available only to the members of the org, and private
instance-level search contexts are available only to site-admins.

("3 FileMatch results").

fields.name: documentationPage
fields.description:
Returns the documentation page corresponding to the given path ID, where the empty string "/"
refers to the current tree entry and can be used to walk all documentation below this tree entry.

Currently this method is only supported on the root tree entry of a repository.

A pathID refers to all the structured documentation slugs emitted by the LSIF indexer joined together
with a slash, starting at the slug corresponding to this tree entry filepath. A pathID and filepath may
sometimes look similar, but are not equal. Some examples include:

* A documentation page under filepath `internal/pkg/mux` with pathID `/Router/ServeHTTP/examples`.
* A documentation page under filepath `/` (repository root) with pathID `/internal/pkg/mux/Router/ServeHTTP/examples`

In other words, a path ID is said to be the path to the page, relative to the tree entry
filepath.

The components of the pathID are chosen solely by the LSIF indexer, and may vary over time or
even dynamically based on e.g. project size. The same is true of pages, e.g. an LSIF indexer
may choose to create new pages if an API surface exceeds some threshold size.

fields.name: documentationPathInfo
fields.description:
Returns the documentation pth info corresponding to the given path ID, where the empty string "/"
refers to the current tree entry and can be used to walk all documentation below this tree entry.

Currently this method is only supported on the root tree entry of a repository.

See @documentationPage for information about what a pathID refers to.

This method is optimal for e.g. walking the entire documentation path structure of a repository,
whereas documentationPage would require you to fetch the content for all pages you walk (not true
of path info.)

If maxDepth is specified, pages will be recursively returned up to that depth. Default max depth
is one (immediate child pages only.)

If ignoreIndex is true, empty index pages (pages whose only purpose is to describe pages below
them) will not qualify as a page in relation to the maxDepth property: index pages will be
recursively followed and included until a page with actual content is found, and only then will
the depth be considered to increment. Default is false.

This returns a JSON value because GraphQL has terrible support for recursive data structures: https://github.com/graphql/graphql-spec/issues/91

The exact structure of the return value is documented here:
https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/sourcegraph/sourcegraph%24+type+DocumentationPathInfoResult+struct&patternType=literal&case=yes

fields.name: documentationDefinitions
fields.description: A list of definitions of the symbol described by the given documentation path ID, if any.

fields.name: documentationReferences
fields.description: A list of references of the symbol under the given document position.

args.name: pathID
args.description: The documentation path ID, e.g. from the documentationPage return value.

args.description:
When specified, indicates that this request should be paginated and
to fetch results starting at this cursor.
A future request can be made for more results by passing in the

args.name: first
args.description:
When specified, indicates that this request should be paginated and
the first N results (relative to the cursor) should be returned. i.e.
how many results to return per page.

fields.description: The user's username.

fields.name: email
fields.description:
The user's primary email address.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.
fields.deprecationReason: use emails instead

fields.name: displayName
fields.description: The display name chosen by the user.

fields.name: avatarURL
fields.description: The URL of the user's avatar image.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL to the user's profile on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: settingsURL
fields.description: The URL to the user's settings.

fields.name: createdAt
fields.description: The date when the user account was created on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: updatedAt
fields.description: The date when the user account was last updated on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: siteAdmin
fields.description:
Whether the user is a site admin.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

fields.name: builtinAuth
fields.description: Whether the user account uses built in auth.

fields.name: latestSettings
fields.description:
The latest settings for the user.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

fields.name: settingsCascade
fields.description:
All settings for this user, and the individual levels in the settings cascade (global > organization > user)
that were merged to produce the final merged settings.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

fields.name: configurationCascade
fields.description: DEPRECATED
fields.deprecationReason: Use settingsCascade instead. This field is a deprecated alias for it and will be removed in a future release.

fields.name: organizations
fields.description: The organizations that this user is a member of.

fields.name: organizationMemberships
fields.description: This user's organization memberships.

fields.name: tags
fields.description:
Tags associated with the user. These are used for internal site management and feature selection.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

fields.name: usageStatistics
fields.description: The user's usage statistics on Sourcegraph.

fields.name: eventLogs
fields.description: The user's events on Sourcegraph.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n event logs from the list.

args.name: eventName
args.description: Only return events matching this event name

fields.name: emails
fields.description:
The user's email addresses.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

fields.name: accessTokens
fields.description:
The user's access tokens (which grant to the holder the privileges of the user). This consists
of all access tokens whose subject is this user.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n access tokens from the list.

fields.name: externalAccounts
fields.description: A list of external accounts that are associated with the user.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n external accounts from the list.

fields.name: session
fields.description:
The user's currently active session.
Only the currently authenticated user can access this field. Site admins are not able to access sessions for
other users.

fields.name: viewerCanAdminister
fields.description:
Whether the viewer has admin privileges on this user. The user has admin privileges on their own user, and
site admins have admin privileges on all users.

fields.name: viewerCanChangeUsername
fields.description:
Whether the viewer can change the username of this user.
The user can change their username unless auth.disableUsernameChanges is set.
Site admins can always change the username of any user.

fields.name: surveyResponses
fields.description:
The user's survey responses.
Only the user and site admins can access this field.

fields.name: databaseID
fields.description:
The unique numeric ID for the user.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

fields.name: namespaceName
fields.description: The name of this user namespace's component. For users, this is the username.

fields.name: repositories
fields.description: Repositories from external services owned by this user.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n repositories from the list.

args.name: query
args.description: Return repositories whose names match the query.

args.name: after
args.description: An opaque cursor that is used for pagination.

args.name: cloned
args.description: Include cloned repositories.

args.name: notCloned
args.description: Include repositories that are not yet cloned and for which cloning is not in progress.

args.name: indexed
args.description: Include repositories that have a text search index.

args.name: notIndexed
args.description: Include repositories that do not have a text search index.

args.name: externalServiceID
args.description: Only include repositories from this external service.

fields.name: publicRepositories
fields.description: publicRepositories returns the repos listed in user_public_repos for this user

fields.name: campaigns
fields.description: A list of campaigns applied under this user's namespace.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n campaigns from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: state
args.description: Only return campaigns in this state.

args.name: viewerCanAdminister
args.description: Only include campaigns that the viewer can administer.

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use batchChanges instead.

fields.name: campaignsCodeHosts
fields.description:
Returns a connection of configured external services accessible by this user, for usage with campaigns.
These are all code hosts configured on the Sourcegraph instance that are supported by campaigns. They are
connected to CampaignCredential resources, if one has been created for the code host connection before.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n code hosts from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

fields.deprecationReason: campaigns have been renamed to batch changes. Use batchChangesCodeHosts instead.

fields.name: batchChanges
fields.description: A list of batch changes applied under this user's namespace.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n batch changes from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

args.name: state
args.description: Only return batch changes in this state.

args.name: viewerCanAdminister
args.description: Only include batch changes that the viewer can administer.

fields.name: batchChangesCodeHosts
fields.description:
Returns a connection of configured external services accessible by this user, for usage with batch changes.
These are all code hosts configured on the Sourcegraph instance that are supported by batch changes. They are
connected to BatchChangesCredential resources, if one has been created for the code host connection before.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n code hosts from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

fields.name: permissionsInfo
fields.description:
The permissions information of the user over repositories.
It is null when there is no permissions data stored for the user.

fields.name: monitors
fields.description: A list of monitors owned by the user or her organization.

args.name: first
args.description: Returns the first n monitors from the list.

args.name: after
args.description: Opaque pagination cursor.

fields.name: urlForSiteAdminBilling
fields.description:
The URL to view this user's customer information (for Sourcegraph.com site admins).
Only Sourcegraph.com site admins may query this field.
FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.

types.name: UserActivePeriod
types.description: A period of time in which a set of users have been active.

enumValues.name: TODAY
enumValues.description: Since today at 00:00 UTC.

enumValues.name: THIS_WEEK
enumValues.description: Since the latest Monday at 00:00 UTC.

enumValues.name: THIS_MONTH
enumValues.description: Since the first day of the current month at 00:00 UTC.

enumValues.name: ALL_TIME
enumValues.description: All time.

types.name: UserConnection
types.description: A list of users.

fields.name: nodes
fields.description: A list of users.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description:
The total count of users in the connection. This total count may be larger
than the number of nodes in this object when the result is paginated.

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: Pagination information.

types.name: UserEmail
types.description: A user's email address.

fields.name: email
fields.description: The email address.

fields.name: isPrimary
fields.description:
Whether the email address is the user's primary email address. Currently this is defined as the earliest
email address associated with the user, preferring verified emails to unverified emails.

fields.name: verified
fields.description: Whether the email address has been verified by the user.

fields.name: verificationPending
fields.description: Whether the email address is pending verification.

fields.name: user
fields.description: The user associated with this email address.

fields.name: viewerCanManuallyVerify
fields.description:
Whether the viewer has privileges to manually mark this email address as verified (without the user going
through the normal verification process). Only site admins have this privilege.

types.name: UserEvent
types.description: A user event.

enumValues.name: STAGEMANAGE
enumValues.description: Product stages

types.name: UserPermission
types.description: A user (identified either by username or email address) with its repository permission.

inputFields.name: bindID
inputFields.description:
Depending on the bindID option in the permissions.userMapping site configuration property,
the elements of the list are either all usernames (bindID of "username") or all email
addresses (bindID of "email").

inputFields.name: permission
inputFields.description: The highest level of repository permission.

types.name: UserUsageStatistics
types.description:
UserUsageStatistics describes a user's usage statistics.
This information is visible to all viewers.

fields.name: searchQueries
fields.description: The number of search queries that the user has performed.

fields.name: pageViews
fields.description: The number of page views that the user has performed.

fields.name: codeIntelligenceActions
fields.description: The number of code intelligence actions that the user has performed.

fields.name: findReferencesActions
fields.description: The number of find-refs actions that the user has performed.

fields.name: lastActiveTime
fields.description: The last time the user was active (any action, any platform).

fields.name: lastActiveCodeHostIntegrationTime
fields.description: The last time the user was active on a code host integration.

types.name: VersionContext
types.description:
(experimental) A version context. Used to change the set of default repository and revisions searched.
Note: We do not expose the list of repositories and revisions in the version context. This is intentional. However, if a need arises we can add it in.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the version context.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the version context.

types.name: VirtualFile
types.description: A virtual file is an arbitrary file that is generated in memory.

fields.name: path
fields.description: The full path (relative to the root) of this file.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The base name (i.e., file name only) of this file.

fields.name: isDirectory
fields.description: False because this is a file, not a directory.

fields.name: content
fields.description: The content of this file.

fields.name: byteSize
fields.description: The file size in bytes.

fields.name: binary
fields.description: Whether or not it is binary.

fields.name: richHTML
fields.description:
The file rendered as rich HTML, or an empty string if it is not a supported
rich file type.
This HTML string is already escaped and thus is always safe to render.

fields.name: url
fields.description: Not implemented.

fields.name: canonicalURL
fields.description: Not implemented.

fields.name: externalURLs
fields.description: Not implemented.

fields.name: highlight
fields.description: Highlight the file.

args.name: highlightLongLines
args.description:
If highlightLongLines is true, lines which are longer than 2000 bytes are highlighted.
2000 bytes is enabled. This may produce a significant amount of HTML
which some browsers (such as Chrome, but not Firefox) may have trouble
rendering efficiently.

types.name: VisibleApplyPreviewTargets
types.description: A preview entry to a repository to which the user has access.

types.name: VisibleApplyPreviewTargetsAttach
types.description: A preview entry where no changeset existed before matching the changeset spec.

fields.name: changesetSpec
fields.description: The changeset spec from this entry.

types.name: VisibleApplyPreviewTargetsDetach
types.description:
A preview entry where no changeset spec exists for the changeset currently in
the target batch change.

fields.name: changeset
fields.description: The changeset from this entry.

types.name: VisibleApplyPreviewTargetsUpdate
types.description: A preview entry where a changeset matches the changeset spec.

fields.name: changesetSpec
fields.description: The changeset spec from this entry.

fields.name: changeset
fields.description: The changeset from this entry.

types.name: VisibleChangesetApplyPreview
types.description:
One preview entry in the list of all previews against a batch spec. Each mapping
between changeset specs and current changesets yields one of these. It describes
which operations are taken against which changeset spec and changeset to ensure the
desired state is met.

fields.name: operations
fields.description: The operations to take to achieve the desired state.

fields.name: delta
fields.description:
The delta between the current changeset state and what the new changeset spec
envisions the changeset to look like.

fields.name: targets
fields.description: The target entities in this preview entry.

types.name: VisibleChangesetSpec
types.description:
A changeset spec is an immutable description of the desired state of a changeset in a batch change. To
create a changeset spec, use the createChangesetSpec mutation.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
The unique ID for a changeset spec.

The ID is unguessable (i.e., long and randomly generated, not sequential). This is important
even though repository permissions also apply to viewers of changeset specs, because being
allowed to view a repository should not entitle a person to view all not-yet-published
changesets for that repository. Consider a batch change to fix a security vulnerability: the
batch change author may prefer to prepare all of the changesets in private so that the window
between revealing the problem and merging the fixes is as short as possible.

fields.name: type
fields.description: The type of changeset spec.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the changeset.

fields.name: expiresAt
fields.description:
The date, if any, when this changeset spec expires and is automatically purged. A changeset
spec never expires (and this field is null) if its batch spec has been applied.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name, description and optional `specifiedByUrl`, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields`, `interfaces`, and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Included when true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Skipped when true.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted using the Markdown syntax, as specified by [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org/).

directives.name: specifiedBy
directives.description: Exposes a URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.

args.name: url
args.description: The URL that specifies the behaviour of this scalar.
